definition: A sudden event that causes great damage or suffering.
examples: The flood was a major disaster for the town.
Good planning can reduce the impact of a disaster.

extra.memory_tip: Disaster = a day that ‘disastrously’ falls apart.

definition: To run away from danger or from a place.
examples: People fled the building when the alarm rang.
Birds flee to warmer places in winter.

definition: A break or crack in something, especially a bone; to break or crack.
examples: The X-ray showed a small fracture. (noun)
He fractured his wrist while skating. (verb)
They felt immense pride in their work.
The whale is an immense creature.

definition: Very strong in degree; deep or extreme.
examples: The heat was intense at midday.
She has an intense focus when she studies.

definition: To look into something carefully to find facts or the truth.
examples: The police are investigating the theft.
Scientists investigate how plants grow.

extra.memory_tip: Investigate = in + vestiga (trace): trace the facts.

definition: To make a sudden, unsteady movement.
examples: The bus lurched to a stop. (verb)
With a lurch, the boat swung left. (noun)

definition: Very important or large; a person with a higher military rank or a main subject of study.
examples: The team made a major change. (adjective)
She is a major. (noun)

definition: Less important or smaller; a person under the legal age of adulthood.
examples: It was a minor error. (adjective)
Minors must be with an adult. (noun)

definition: To make someone very afraid; to turn organic matter into stone over time.
examples: The loud bang petrified the cat.
Wood can petrify and become stone over ages.

extra.memory_tip: Petrify = ‘petra’ (rock) + -fy: make like rock—or freeze with fear.

definition: To say what you think will happen in the future.
examples: Can you predict tomorrow’s weather?
The model predicts faster growth next year.

extra.memory_tip: Pre- (before) + dict (say) = say before it happens.

definition: Likely to do or suffer from something; lying flat, face down.
examples: He is prone to headaches.
The injured player lay prone on the field.

extra.memory_tip: Prone = more prone to happen to you.

definition: Thinly spread or not dense; few and far between.
examples: Trees were sparse on the dry plain.
Attendance was sparse after the storm.

definition: To fall or cause to fall over; to remove from power.
examples: The stack of books toppled over.
Protesters aimed to topple the corrupt leader.

definition: Relating to a town or city.
examples: Urban areas have many tall buildings.
Urban transport includes buses and trains.
